ownCloud : Your Personal Network Drive

Posted on January 4, 2018 by Kartik B. under Web Hosting

ownCloud is a suite of client–server software for creating file hosting services and using them. ownCloud is functionally very similar to the widely used Dropbox, with the primary functional difference being that the Server Edition of ownCloud is free and open-source, and thereby allowing anyone to install and operate it without charge on a private server.

PREREQUISITES

Before you begin this guide, there are some important steps that you need to complete on your server.

  • you’ll need to have a LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL, and PHP) stack installed on your instance. If you don’t have these components already installed and configured, you can use this guide to learn how to install Apache on Ubuntu.

 

STEP 1 — INSTALLING ADDITIONAL PHP MOUDLES

 

Install the required modules by issuing the following commands in a terminal:

sudo apt-get install php-zip php-curl php-xml php-mbstring php-gd

 

STEP 2 — DOWNLOADING AND EXTRACTING OWNCLOUD

 

Go ahead and download the latest Tarball Here under Resources

or if on terminal you can do via copying the link and typing :

wget https://download.owncloud.org/community/owncloud-x.y.z.tar.bz2

Now you can extract the archive contents , type:

tar -xjf owncloud-x.y.z.tar.bz2

This unpacks to a single owncloud directory.

[x.y.z denotes the latest version available]

 

STEP 3 — SETTING UP WITH APACHE

 

Copy the ownCloud directory to document root of your Web server.

cp -r owncloud /var/www

Create a owncloud.conf file by 

nano /etc/apache2/sites-available/owncloud.conf

with these lines in it,

Alias /owncloud "/var/www/owncloud/" 

<Directory /var/www/owncloud/> 
Options +FollowSymlinks 
AllowOverride All 

<IfModule mod_dav.c>
 Dav off 
</IfModule> 
SetEnv HOME /var/www/owncloud 
SetEnv HTTP_HOME /var/www/owncloud 

</Directory>

Then create a symlink to /etc/apache2/sites-enabled:

ln -s /etc/apache2/sites-available/owncloud.conf /etc/apache2/sites-enabled/owncloud.conf

Open 000-default.conf file by 

nano  /etc/apache2/sites-enabled/000-default.conf 

and change path of DocumentRoot to /var/www/owncloud

DocumentRoot /var/www/owncloud

 

STEP 4 — ADDITIONAL APACHE MODULES

 

For ownCloud to work correctly, we need the following modules . Enable them by running:

a2enmod rewrite
a2enmod headers
a2enmod env
a2enmod dir
a2enmod mime
a2enmod ssl
a2ensite default-ssl

Now restart Apache

service apache2 restart

 

 

STEP 5 — THE INSTALLATION WIZARD

 

To run this, change the ownership on your ownCloud directories to your HTTP user

chown -R www-data:www-data /var/www/owncloud/

We need to create a database for owncloud, for that type following commands . Here we are taking username as dbadmin and password as Apassword

sudo mysql -u root -p
CREATE USER 'dbadmin'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'Apassword';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON *.* TO 'dbadmin'@'localhost' WITH GRANT OPTION;
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;
exit

When the ownCloud prerequisites are fulfilled and all ownCloud files are installed, the last step to completing the installation is running the Installation Wizard. This involves following steps:

Point your web browser to your external ip address (you can see it by typing curl icanhazip.com in terminal )

 

 

 

Enter your desired administrator’s username and password. (These are not the username and password we entered for the database)

 

 

Under the Storage & Database in Configure Database, add your database username and password

Add any database name you want

Click “Finish Setup”.

Page will reload and will take you to the login menu

 

 

 

 

Login into it and you will see the dashboard of the ownCloud.

 

 

Download the ownCloud Manual to know about all the features

Congratulations, you have reached to the end of this guide. Hope you had fun installing with us. Subscribe here for more such guides.
